bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 165, Number 173 (Thursday, October 31, 2019)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BURCHETT:H.R. 4944.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV,Section 3, Clause 2. The Congress shall have Power todispose of and make all needful Rules and Regulationsrespecting the Territory or other Property belonging to theUnited States; and nothing in this Constitution shall be soconstrued as to Prejudice any Claims of the United States, orof any particular State.[Page H8719]

item.title: Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Small Business.

summary.text:
Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 2019

This bill directs the Small Business Administration to approve or decline an applicant seeking a license to operate as a small business investment company (SBIC) within certain specified timelines, and it requires an applicant to successfully pass a Federal Bureau of Investigation background check before it may become an SBIC.

bill.title: Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 2019

item.title: Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 2019
To require the Small Business Administration to issue licenses under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 within particular time frames, and for other purposes.
Small Business Investment Improvement Act of 2019

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Small Business.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
